title: Frontend - Rest Timer for Workout Tracker
body:
# What type of PR is this? (Check all that apply)

- [X] ‚ú®**feature**: Introduces completely new code or new features.
- [ ] üêõ**fix**: Implements changes that fix a bug. Ideally, reference an issue if present.
- [ ] ‚ôªÔ∏è**refactor**: Includes any code-related change that is neither a fix nor a feature.
- [ ] ‚úÖ**build**: Encompasses all changes related to the build of the software, including changes to dependencies or the addition of new ones.
- [ ] ‚ö°Ô∏è**test**: Pertains to all changes regarding tests, whether adding new tests or modifying existing ones.
- [ ] üö∞**ci**: Involves all changes related to the configuration of continuous integration, such as GitHub Actions or other CI systems.
- [ ] üìö**docs**: Includes all changes to documentation, such as README files, or any other documentation present in the repository.
- [ ] üóëÔ∏è**chore**: Captures all changes to the repository that do not fit into the above categories.

# Description

What did you change? How did you change it?
The purpose of this PR is to create a functional rest timer for the workout tracker that has the following functionality:

1. Timer has minutes and seconds field that allows for custom rest times that ONLY accepts numeric whole numbers.
2. Both minutes and seconds fields have to have valid input before a timer can start, if either is empty or both are empty, no timer can be started.
3. Once a timer starts, their minutes and seconds fields cannot be modified to prevent the timer from being changed. The same applies to a timer that has been paused with time remaining, these fields cannot be modified until the timer expires or is reset.
4. A timer can be reset when it is paused or while it is running, both are valid options that do not break the timer.
5. When a timer is reset, the amount of time that it was given is discarded and it goes to a default timer of 00:00 with an empty progress bar.

- [ ] E2E tests

What did you change? How did you change it?

# Tests

# [Optional] Screenshots
![image](https://github.com/UNLV-CS472-672/2024-S-GROUP3-Barbell/assets/38168108/75802712-a64f-45d4-90dc-8f0616d5ecdf)

screen shot shows the basic usage code which was used as a test.

# Documentation

This library was installed locally, then added to the dependencies of our repository using the following command 

`pnpm add react-native-calendars -w `

From there, I ensured it was set to be a field in devDependencies instead of dependencies (inside package.json).




### Basic Usage

Here's a simple example of how to use the Calendar component:

```tsx
import React from 'react'
import { StyleSheet, View } from 'react-native'
import { Calendar, DateData } from 'react-native-calendars'

const App: React.FC = () => {
  const handleDayPress = (day: DateData) => {
    console.log('Selected day:', day.dateString)
  }

  return (
    <View style={styles.container}>
      <Calendar
        onDayPress={handleDayPress}
        markedDates={{
          '2024-04-15': { selected: true, marked: true, selectedColor: '#48476D' }, // streak of 4 days
          '2024-04-17': { selected: true, marked: true, selectedColor: '#48476D' },
          '2024-04-18': { selected: true, marked: true, selectedColor: '#484765' },
          '2024-04-16': { selected: true, marked: true, selectedColor: '#484765' },
          '2024-04-20': { disabled: true, disableTouchEvent: true }, // rest day
        }}
      />
    </View>
  )
}

const styles = StyleSheet.create({
  container: {
    flex: 1,
    justifyContent: 'center',
    alignItems: 'center',
  },
})

export default App
```

### Features

- Pure JS. No Native code required
- Date marking - dot, multi-dot, period, multi-period and custom marking
- Customization of style, content (days, months, etc) and dates
- Detailed documentation and examples
- Swipeable calendar with flexible custom rendering
- Scrolling to today, selecting dates, and more
- Allowing or blocking certain dates
- Accessibility support
- Automatic date formatting for different locales




### Version

The current version is `1.1304.1`.

- [ ] Added to README.me
- [ ] Seperate document
- [ ] NO documentation needed

Link to external documentation:

For more detailed documentation, see the [official docs](https://github.com/wix/react-native-calendars).

# [Optional] Are there any post-deployment tasks we need to perform?

make sure to ` pnpm i ` after this is merged in.

title: 156 spotify   generating refresh tokens

labels.name: backend
labels.description: api, interaction with db, server, container

body:
# What type of PR is this? (Check all that apply)

- [X] ‚ú®**feature**: Introduces completely new code or new features.
- [ ] üêõ**fix**: Implements changes that fix a bug. Ideally, reference an issue if present.
- [ ] ‚ôªÔ∏è**refactor**: Includes any code-related change that is neither a fix nor a feature.
- [ ] ‚úÖ**build**: Encompasses all changes related to the build of the software, including changes to dependencies or the addition of new ones.
- [ ] ‚ö°Ô∏è**test**: Pertains to all changes regarding tests, whether adding new tests or modifying existing ones.
- [ ] üö∞**ci**: Involves all changes related to the configuration of continuous integration, such as GitHub Actions or other CI systems.
- [ ] üìö**docs**: Includes all changes to documentation, such as README files, or any other documentation present in the repository.
- [ ] üóëÔ∏è**chore**: Captures all changes to the repository that do not fit into the above categories.

# Description

What did you change? How did you change it?
My main changes were in the newly created file:
1) `~/apps/expo/src/components/spotify/spotifyToken.tsx`
This file is the most important. It implements authentication via Auth-Session which uses OAuth2 allowing the user to approve and authenticate Barbell to access their Spotify data via the Spotify API.

After the user authenticates the app the initial tokens are generated to further refresh access tokens (as they have a time limit of an hour) when necessary through the refresh token generated.

The access token is checked whenever the updateSpotifyData() function is called (which is the main function to be exported and used by the rest of the team whenever the time comes for the frontend team).

Though it works in isolation, when it comes to more involved usage/use-cases there are a few things to address but those should be handled by the calling files.

One last note was that there are three main functions that can (and should be exported) are:
loginSpotifyButton() : A button to prompt the OAuth login session.

logoutSpotify(): Not a button, but can be added to a button. Just clears tokens and auth code to allow reprompt of login button.

updateTrackData(userID: integer): Pass the userID which should be updated from the running instance of the app. Should ONLY be that of the user which authenticated the app. This is the most important function as it will be used to update data in the database for that user (which is queried and used for all other display stuff like the Spotify widget to be implemented).

# Tests

How was this tested?

- [ ] Unit tests
- [ ] Integration tests
- [ ] E2E tests
- [X] Manual tests
- [ ] Tests were NOT needed
- [ ] Other (explain below)

API Requests, token refresh, etc:
![image](https://github.com/UNLV-CS472-672/2024-S-GROUP3-Barbell/assets/61567471/40488676-4ac8-44f8-a459-dbcbec0ffc4f)

Output on frontend of Barbell (the time is inconsistent as it took me a bit to take the screenshot, ignore that):
![image](https://github.com/UNLV-CS472-672/2024-S-GROUP3-Barbell/assets/61567471/2933cbc1-47d2-4444-8cea-96cd03bb1b6c)


# Documentation

- [ ] Added to README.me
- [ ] Seperate document
- [X] NO documentation needed

Link to external documentation: It's all linked within the files themselves. Refer to file comments.

# [Optional] Are there any post-deployment tasks we need to perform?

Though not post-deployment, there are a few known bugs that I have had issues trying to fix.
1) Issues on `~/apps/expo/src/app/spotify/index.tsx` regarding infinite looping of updateSpotifyData(). Function works normally but for some reason that page keeps invoking it causing the database to have a ton of mutation requests.

2) Need to add a dynamic userID on the above file using the context Marcos implemented a while back. Not relevant as much for this PR as that was just the page being used to test the overall functionality of our Spotify files, but in the end this will be 

3) We should find a way to move the client_id and client_secret (contents of `~/apps/expo/src/components/spotify/spotifyCreds.tsx`) into a .env file to keep it secret and out of main branch.

title: Backend & Frontend -- Implement Clerk User Id to retrive user data

labels.name: backend
labels.description: api, interaction with db, server, container

body:
## Description

When an user gets authenticated using Clerk, Clerk will give them a user d this user Id is different from the one we use. We need to add this user Id to the schema. When a user first signs up we need to create that user and include the user Id that Clerk created, this way when the user signs in again we can use that Clerk user Id to retrieve the user data from the database. This is an urgent issue as many components of our application rely on retrieving logged in user data. 

Include any links, documents, or resources that could provide further context or information relevant to the issue.

## Requirements

Outline the specific objectives and requirements needed to finish the issue. Clearly state what success looks like for this issue.

- [ ] Update the Global Context to use the user data from the logged in user

# Description

- New API
  - `markChatAsReadByChatIdAndUserIdAndChatType` 
    - Takes ChatID, UserID, and ChatType as params, pushes logged in user's ID into readByUserIds array in DB
- Modified `Conversation` component to support this API and feature
  - If the conversation is not read, onPress => push logged in user's ID into DB, push same ID into local list to immediately reflect style change
    - If we didn't push into local list, the style would not immediately change and we would need to wait for another API call
  - Reformatted with Prettier

# Description

Lots of changes, probably more than in the scope of this issue. 
- `Conversation` component
  - Shows the most recent message sent in the DM, who the conversation is with, and how long ago it was sent.
  - Routes user to message page created in #110 
  - Currently has a placeholder icon for a profile photo
- Page from #110 now calls API to get all messages from DM
  - Currently displays the messages in a plain list
    - To do: stylize
- `RotatingBarbellIcon` component
  - New spinning icon to indicate when something is loading
- `DmNotifs` and `Conversation` components both display `RotatingBarbellIcon` when fetching data
- Minor changes to APIs to fetch more data

# Demo
**Note:** This runs fine locally. GitHub makes the video look a little choppy sometimes.
https://github.com/UNLV-CS472-672/2024-S-GROUP3-Barbell/assets/85365584/6ef716c4-4973-4d33-ac8a-4ce70a153377



# How to test
If you want to test the functionality of this on your local machine, `userData` in the global context needs to be set. 
copy:
```
{
  id: 9,
  username: "userNine",
  name: "User Nine",
  status: "ACTIVE",
  streak: 4,
}
```
and paste it in the field of `userData` (which is currently set to null) on the file `apps/expo/src/context/global-context.tsx` (currently line 21).

# Additional notes
Some of the messages may not have the correct `senderId` to match with the `userId` in the demo. This is the fault of me assigning random messages to users within the prisma studio interface. Do not be alarmed.

title: Mixed -- connect Spotify services to component

labels.name: backend
labels.description: api, interaction with db, server, container

body:
Design and implement an API to integrate Spotify's API and get the following information from a user:
* Of currently playing track * 
* Name of album + url to album image
* Artist(s) + url
* Song title + url
* Is a song currently playing?
* Amount of time elapsed for song + total length of song

All fields can be null, depends on if a song is currently playing (that field will always return true if a song is playing, false otherwise).

* Note *
* Use this link as reference on what fields to get from .json returned by Spotify. Second link provides rough idea of how to approach API
* https://developer.spotify.com/documentation/web-api/reference/get-the-users-currently-playing-track
* https://medium.com/@alagappan.dev/create-a-now-playing-widget-using-the-spotify-web-api-in-react-a6cb564ed923

# Description

Updated prisma schema to include a new model for data (named SpotifyData) we get through the Spotify API regarding a user's currently playing track. Also updated user model to include a new field (one-to-one) for said data, optional as we should wait to see if the user will approve using Spotify on their account (future issue). 

# Tests

Explanation:
I tested it locally by just creating a few new rows and adding relevant data fields making sure of a few things:
   1) Each user could exist without a spotify field, but not vice versa (success).
   2) All fields must be initialized to null outside of isPlaying (used for frontend display logic) (success).

# Documentation

- [ ] Added to README.me
- [x] Seperate document
- [ ] NO documentation needed

Link to external documentation: https://developer.spotify.com/documentation/web-api/reference/get-the-users-currently-playing-track

(Above link has information on what kind of data can be found within each .json response through the Spotify API and was used to figure out what types to make each relevant field, as well as which ones to allow as optional fields or not).

Code for the above buttons
```typescript
<Button
  size="xl"
  value="Button 1"
  onPress={() => router.replace('/')}
/>
<Button value="Button 2" />
<Button value="Button 3" color="light" />
<Button value="Button 4" color="dark" />
<Button value="Button 5" color="dark" size="xl" />
<Button value="Button 6" color="dark" size="xl" rounded="full" />
<Button
  value="Button 7"
  rounded="xxxl"
  color="light"
  className="flex h-16 justify-center"
/>
<Button value="Button 8" className="flex h-12 w-72 justify-center" />
<Button
  className="flex w-36 flex-row-reverse items-center justify-center gap-x-2 px-2"
  value="Button 9"
  size="xl"
>
  <MaterialIcons name="search" size={24} color="white" />
</Button>
<Button
  color="icon"
  className="flex flex-row items-center justify-center gap-x-4"
>
  <MaterialIcons name="article" size={24} color="black" />
  <Text className="text-xl text-black">Button 10</Text>
</Button>
```
In addition to the default styles, you can add your own custom styling to the button if needed. The button component also accepts children.
When there are no fields specified the default styling is applied.

title: Frontend - OAuth Error
body:
### What's happening
The sign in page will throw an OAuth error if the user presses the buttons too quickly. 
___
### How to replicate
Either rapidly click one of the sign in/sign up buttons, or click sign in then sign up very quickly. Make sure you are **not signed in**
___
### Image(s)
![Screenshot 2024-03-07 at 11 51 37‚ÄØPM](https://github.com/UNLV-CS472-672/2024-S-GROUP3-Barbell/assets/85365584/54f06e21-992c-4de5-b104-2c7fa07b4d9d)
___
### Notes
Should be an easy fix for a newer developer to do. Probably just set a timer for 0.5s or so when a button is clicked that disables the other buttons. Or you can wait until the browser opens before allowing a button click again.

As mentioned in the PR, setting up a local environment for everyone truly is tough, especially Android development, which is not very Linux friendly, we encountered enough struggles and challenge if we want to be unified in a Docker container, that's why this issue was created, to ensure all versions are up to date and able to have a native build for android

Since there is quite a change in this, I will change this PR to fix the native build, and other version conflicts we have prior to setup.

## Pre-testing

- [ ] Make sure you have 2 .env files
- [ ] Make sure you have .gitignore in apps/expo,
- [ ] Make sure you have 
- [ ] Make sure you are on Windows or Linux.

## Checklist

- [ ] Commands to run the repo have been changing, you can follow the old one,
- [ ] Or use the one that has been updated
- [ ] At the root repo. run
- [ ] `pnpm clean`
- [ ] `pnpm store prune`
- [ ] `pnpm i`
- [ ] `pnpm i`
- [ ] `pnpm db:stuidio`
- [ ] Open a new terminal, at the root again
- [ ] `pnpm run dev`
- [ ] Open a new terminal, navigate to apps/expo

`The next 2 steps can be ignored if you don't have Java version 17, or 11 installed.`

- [ ] If you want to test the native build, navigate to the `apps/expo/android` folder, and locate a file name `local.properties`, change the line within `sdk.dir=C:\\Users\\nvktv\\AppData\\Local\\Android\\sdk` to your machine, the SDK is fixed there. If you have a Mac and still want to try this out, read [this](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27620262/sdk-location-not-found-define-location-with-sdk-dir-in-the-local-properties-fil)
- [ ] `pnpm expo run:android` (ONLY RUN THIS IF YOU HAVE JAVA VERSION 17, or 11? installed, and follow the step above, otherwise, ignore this)

`Otherwise, run this`

- [ ] `pnpm expo start`
- [ ] You should have Prisma Studio running, the website running at port 3000, and our app running on the android virtual machine.
- [ ] All dependencies errors resolved, as well as native build 

The reason why we need a native build is simple, if everything works natively, the same will work if we export that build to an APK, or an actual app. Especially when we might use third parties services that are outside of the Expo.
